It's both, dished up with style by the Norwegians. Am I wrong, or do the Scandinavians have a knack for taking us out of the same ole horror recipe, and delivering something where the police, forensics, and physicians are involved, besides a father of a victim who just won't give up on his daughter, who is in a pitiful condition. There aren't any malformed degenerates, no zombies(thank God) running around killing and devouring.
I won't go any further. It would really spoil the plot of this terrific movie.

Unusual and engrossing.  Love the bleak Scandinavian style and setting.

*** 3 Stars ***  A dark, disturbing and carefully paced flick that feels a lot like a low-budget '80s horror movie - if it was made by a bunch of crazed Norwegians on acid.  I mean, this is about as odd as it gets - but it's weirdly entertaining if you don't mind, well, people being attacked by power drill-wielding psychopaths (or are they alien zombies?)  And only in a European flick would the fearless hero (and I do mean fearless) be an overweight, middle-aged music teacher.  There are some pretty young women here - well, pretty before they start spewing toxic black vomit.  If you're feeling adventurous (and that means you won't post vicious reviews because you expected something a bit more mainstream), give it a watch.

This film from Norway is too weird to be interesting. A woman jogs through the woods and is attacked by a guy with a cordless power-drill. Her body rises in the morgue and she makes her way home. Her dad sees her covered in mud sitting at her computer and she says nothing and he just takes that as normal. Later in the night he wakes to find her still at her computer where she's typed "Help" over and over and over again.

Another woman is attacked. She also re-animates in the hospital.

Somehow the father is able to track down who's turned his daughter into a zombie. Guys in orange overalls are going around drilling holes in girl's heads and filling them with some black ooze.

Later on it turns out that the zombies can make other people zombies by vomiting the black ooze over them.

This film is too strange and has no point.

If you're not into Indy or low budget films with brains (pun intended), then you won't like this film. Horror fans, and those who aren't afraid to read subtitles will enjoy this film. Its arthouse-ish and interesting. One reviewer complained about movies needing a beginning and an end and that makes me laugh out loud! So many big budget films these days can't come up with an ending no matter how much cash they splash, and horror films have always been "outside the box" in every way, so to say this film wasn't good for those reasons is perfectly ludicrous. Four stars because it was unclear wether the digitalizing of some shots was due to internet connection or just (intentionally?) poor cinematography. Overall, I say watch this film if you are a fan of the genre, and give it more than the 5 minutes other poor reviewers gave it..

Film started out well and seemed to be developing into a real thriller. However it faded in the last and actually left us with no precise ending although there were a few clues to allow the viewer to decide the exact cause of the disease. I got a feeling there was a message hidden in there somewhere perhaps linking some sort of industrialization/big oil company plot done in secrecy. It would have been a better movie if it was a lot more straightforward in what the director was trying to convey.

This is definitely something different and original. I went into this film without really knowing what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised. It is somewhat slow moving at points, but the twisted last 20 minutes of the film made the entire movie tie together in an unexpected turn. At times somewhat comical near the end, it still delivers. I prefer to watch European horror style films so I have no complaints about the subtitles. The acting of the father is very realistic of what a man caught in his situation would do and his actions are also very realistic. Worth a watch if your looking for something rather offbeat and somewhat unique for its genre ending.

While the cover picture depicts something from the realms of Hostel or Saw, this is definitely not a torture film.  A Norwegian film with subtitles, Dark Souls is a good horror/mystery.  When his daughter is attacked by a drill-wielding maniac, and the police seem unable to help, a father sets out to discover who and what this attacker is.  As the film progresses, the stranger things become and you are soon in the middle of an almost alien conspiracy.  While the gore exists, it is not over-the-top and there is no nudity or gratuitous sex.  The movie is well-acted and steady-paced.  If you are looking for a hack-and-slash, or zombie movie, you will probably be disappointed, as will those who need a nice, neat explanation for what is happening.  However, the movie does not take itself too seriously; it was entertaining and well worth the watch.
